intro: Developer on the Freedombone project: a system to help you run your own internet and mesh network services

post.body: This weekend I am mainly working on IPFS integration for the mesh version of Freedombone. The Freedombone project doesn't yet have a zeronet site, but it's surely only a matter of time. qTox is already working well on my test mesh, and is brain-dead simple to use.
I think ZeroMe looks quite promising. It would be nice to have a mesh version of this, but as far as I know the ZeroID system is centralised and so can't work without the internet.

comment.body: @Gallium: blimey. I didn't know that zeronet had a socnet
Trackers I can get around, because I can just install one on every peer, and I'm pretty sure that works. It's the not being able to set an ID which doesn't.
In the current system I'm using tox IDs for identity. If I could find a way to substitute that for zeroID that would be better.

@ks: I'm not sure that anything based upon proof of work world be a good idea. Keep in mind that mesh networks may be deployed quickly in emergency situations using any available laptops. Conserving battery power matters. There can also be solar powered off-grid installations. Proof of work just wastes electrical power.
Probably to get zeronet working on a mesh I'll need to study the code and see what it's doing then add an extra command option to enable or disable the relevant stuff.
But zeronet is a pretty good user experience, so it's probably worth the effort.
Not sure how that's supposed to work. I get a tiny popup in the middle of the screen which does nothing.
"Remote XUL: This page uses an unsupported technology that is no longer available by default"
